importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current context of China’s new rare-earth export controls being announced just before key diplomatic meetings.
The effective date of the new export restrictions on rare-earth metals and related equipment, marking when the restrictions will officially begin to apply.
The expected date of Trump’s visit to South Korea for the APEC summit, where he is scheduled to meet with President Xi Jinping, placing the export controls in a strategic diplomatic context.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the announcement of the export controls and their enforcement gives the US and other countries time to react and adjust supply chains, creating strategic pressure during ongoing trade negotiations.

keyTakeAways: China has tightened export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions: holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium, bringing the total to 12 restricted metals.
The restrictions include export controls on specialized technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals, effective from December 1, 2025.
Foreign companies must obtain special approvals from Beijing and justify the intended use of products containing rare-earth metals, especially if they contain at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals.
China cites national security and the threat of sensitive military applications as justification, pointing to cases of unauthorized transfer of Chinese rare-earth materials to military entities.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, having imported $22.8 million worth in 2023, with 70% of its rare-earth imports coming from China between 2020 and 2023.
Rare-earth metals are critical for defence technologies such as F-35 fighter jets, submarines, missiles, and AI semiconductors, making the controls strategically significant.
The move is seen as a signalling tactic before the Trump-Xi meeting at the APEC summit in South Korea, aimed at strengthening China’s negotiating leverage.
China remains the world’s largest producer and processor of rare-earth metals (60% mining, 90% processing), giving it significant supply-side influence.
The US has previously restricted China’s access to semiconductors, and China’s action shows its ability to reciprocate and disrupt US industrial capabilities.
Exemptions exist for exports related to emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, or disaster relief.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has announced new and expanded export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five newly added ones (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium), and on specialized refining equipment. The restrictions, effective from December 1, 2025, require foreign companies to obtain Beijing approval and justify the intended use of products containing rare-earth metals. China cites national security concerns, particularly the unauthorized transfer of rare-earth materials to military uses, as justification. The move comes just weeks before a high-stakes diplomatic meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit in South Korea, positioning the controls as a strategic signal to strengthen China’s bargaining power. The U.S. is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, with 70% of its imports originating from China, and relies on these metals for critical defence technologies such as fighter jets, submarines, missiles, and AI semiconductors. Experts from CSIS and the University of Montana describe this as a deliberate 'pre-meeting choreography' to leverage China's dominant position in the rare-earth supply chain, deepening the U.S. technological and industrial vulnerabilities during ongoing trade negotiations.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
